close_symbols: lfs_cache_t (full struct definition, including the type of the member "buffer")
pcache->buffer (the exact declaration if separate from lfs_cache_t)
lfs_t (full struct definition) and the type/definition of lfs->cfg (the config struct)
explanation:
1) lfs_cache_t (and pcache->buffer): The central question for the MISRA rule is whether the cache buffer being written via memcpy is declared const-qualified. You must see the exact declaration of the buffer member (e.g. uint8_t buffer[] vs const uint8_t *buffer) to determine if the code writes through a non-const pointer or illegally writes through a const-qualified pointer.

2) pcache->buffer (if declared separately): If the buffer member is declared via a separate typedef or macro, include that exact declaration so there is no ambiguity about const qualification.

3) lfs_t and lfs->cfg (config struct): The function uses lfs->cfg fields and passes around cache structs; the config may document ownership/immutability semantics or contain typedefs that affect cache member types. Seeing these structs ensures buffer ownership/intent (mutable vs immutable) and rules out indirection that could change constness.

4) lfs_bd_flush (prototype/implementation): lfs_bd_prog calls lfs_bd_flush which operates on the same cache objects. If lfs_bd_flush writes to the cache buffer or expects mutable cache state, that demonstrates the buffer must be non-const. Conversely, if it only reads, buffer might be const. The implementation clarifies whether the cache must be mutable.

5) lfs_cache_zero and lfs_cache_drop (prototypes/implementations): These helper functions manipulate cache contents; their implementations show whether other code writes into pcache/rcache buffers, supporting the determination of whether the cache buffer should be non-const.

6) Definitions of LFS_BLOCK_INLINE and LFS_BLOCK_NULL: While not directly about pointer constness, these constants determine control flow (e.g. inline block handling) which can affect whether buffers are treated as mutable or read-only in some code paths; include to fully understand intent and usage.

Providing these symbols lets the next analyst determine whether any pointer writes in lfs_bd_prog (memcpy into pcache->buffer) violate the MISRA guideline requiring pointers to be const-qualified when possible.
